anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges in dealing with this application observed In 1947-48 unprecedented events occurred in Delhi with the result that in some cases the whereabouts of close relations were not known for months. In the present case not a syllable is to be found on the record to show that the affidavit of Amar Nath was untrue in any particular. That being so, I have no doubt that there was sufficient cause for not filing the appeal in time.

holdings.text: Legal representatives of Sham Sunder entitled to be subrogated to the rights and priorities of Daulatram under the mortgage dated January 21, 1944 as against the later mortgage of Jagdish Chand even though there was no agreement in writing stipulating for such a right.

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned in these two appeals with the claim made by the legal representatives of Sham Sunder that they were entitled by reason of their discharging the mortgage-debt of Daultram to whom they had paid Rs. 84,000/- out of the mortgage amount of Rs. 1,25,000/-to be subrogated to the rights and priorities of Daulatram under the mortgage dated

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held no express written agreement required; appellant did not dispute this view; new argument on intention not permitted as not pleaded earlier, no issue framed or evidence led.

holdings.text: No express written agreement stipulating for subrogation is necessary to entitle a creditor redeeming a prior mortgage to claim subrogation under equitable principles invoked via s.6 Punjab Laws Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on their behalf that though the Transfer of Property Act did not in terms apply, yet the equitable principle underlying its s. 92 viz., the right of a secured creditor who had discharged a prior encumbrancer to be subrogated to the rights and priorities of the mortgagee who he had redeemed, could nevertheless be invoked under s. 6 of the Punjab Laws Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge erred in requiring specific agreement; High Court correctly reversed; Supreme Court notes appellant does not dispute correctness.

holdings.text: Appellant not permitted to argue that intention of Sham Sunder was not to keep prior charge alive, rebutting presumption for subrogation, as this was not raised in pleadings, no issue framed, no evidence led, and not urged before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Accepting the Law, as expounded by Sir Richard Couch in Gokuldass Gopaldass v. Ram Bux Scochand 1 , in the following terms In India the art of conveyancing has been and is of a very simple character. Their Lordships cannot find that a formal transfer of a mortgage is ever made, or an intention to keep it alive ever formally expressed The obvious question to ask in the interests of 1 1884 L. R. 11 1. A. 126,133-134. justice, equity, and good conscience, is, what was the intention of the party paying off the charge?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question of intention is factual requiring pleadings, issue, evidence; only objection earlier was lack of written agreement; too late at Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Mukhamal as purchaser of plot No.14 entitled to marshalling under s.56 TPA, directing Lajwanti to satisfy debt first from other properties like plot 44.

anchor.surface_text: Now Mukhamal who had been impleaded as a subsequent transferee in Lajwantis suit claimed that he was entitled to marshalling on the principle to be found in s. 56 of the Transfer of Property Act which runs as follows If the owner of two or more properties mortgages them to one person and then sells one or more of the properties to another person., the buyer is, in the absence of a contract to the contrary, entitled to have the mortgage-debt satisfied out of the property or properties not sold to him, so far as the same will extend, but not so as to prejudice the rights of the mortgagee or persons claiming under him or of any other person who has for consideration acquired an interest in any of the properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly upheld claim; no contract to contrary; trial judge disallowed erroneously.

holdings.text: A purchaser entitled to marshalling under s.56 TPA is not disqualified because he is also a subsequent mortgagee over other properties of the mortgagor.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel urged two points 1 that on a proper construction of s. 56 and the principle underlying it the benefit of marshalling could not be claimed by a purchaser who happened to be a mortgagee in respect of any property belonging to the mortgagor. Learned Counsel pointed out that Mukhamal Gokul Chand had a mortgage under a deed dated February 9, 1944, over certain properties with which the appellant is not concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.56 refers to rights qua purchaser; other mortgage rights irrelevant to claim qua purchaser of specific property; contended construction rejected outright.

holdings.text: Direction for marshalling under s.56 TPA does not prejudice rights of subsequent encumbrancer like Brahm Parkash absent pleading and proof of factual prejudice (e.g., via property values).

anchor.surface_text: The other submission of learned Counsel was that the learned judges failed to give effect to the last portion of s. 56 under which marshalling is not to be permitted so as to prejudice the rights inter alia of the mortgagees or other persons claiming under him, i.e., under the original mortgagor. Learned Counsel pointed out that the appellant having proved his mortgage and the fact that it was subsisting, the learned judges of the High Court ought to have held that any direction as to marshalling must necessarily prejudice him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prejudice is factual question requiring pleading of values etc.; no such plea or evidence at trial or High Court; too late in Supreme Court.

holdings.text: High Court correctly condoned delay in filing appeal under s.5 Limitation Act based on affidavit explaining circumstances due to partition disturbances; no ground to interfere with discretion.

anchor.surface_text: Mukhamals appeal to the High Court-Appeal 28 of 1948 was filed out of time with a petition for condonation of delay under s. 5 of the Indian Limitation Act and the learned judges condoned the delay and entertained the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unprecedented partition events; affidavit unchallenged; judges applied correct principles; discretion properly exercised.

precedents.citation: Gokuldass Gopaldass v. Ram Bux Scochand 1 1884 L. R. 11 1. A. 126,133-134

anchor.surface_text: Gokuldass Gopaldass v. Ram Bux Scochand  1 , in the following terms In India the art of companyveyancing has been and is of a very simple character. Their Lordships cannot find that a formal transfer of a mortgage is ever made, or an intention to keep it alive ever formally expressed The obvious question to ask in the interests of  1   1884  L. R. 11 1. A. 126,133-134.

precedents.case_name: Gokuldass Gopaldass v. Ram Bux Scochand
precedents.cited_proposition: In order to entitle a creditor to claim a right of subrogation it was not necessary that he should have entered into a written agreement stipulating for such a right; the intention of the party paying off the prior charge is key, with a presumption that he intends to keep it alive for his benefit unless rebutted.
precedents.cited_holding: The ordinary rule is that a man having a right to act in either of two ways shall be assumed to have acted according to his interest.

anchor.surface_text: This was the only point urged in these appeals which fail and are dismissed with costsone set payable to the executors of the will of Pt. Sham Sunder.
ways. shall be assumed to have acted according to his interest. In the familiar instance of a tenant for life paying off a charge upon the inheritance

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned in these two appeals with the claim made by the legal representatives of Sham Sunder that they were entitled by reason of their discharging the mortgage-debt of Daultram to whom they had paid Rs. 84,000/- out of the mortgage amount of Rs. 1,25,000/-to be subrogated to the rights and priorities of Daulatram under the mortgage dated
This was the only point urged in these appeals which fail and are dismissed with costsone set payable to the executors of the will of Pt. Sham Sunder.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on their behalf that though the Transfer of Property Act did not in terms apply, yet the equitable principle underlying its s. 92 viz., the right of a secured creditor who had discharged a prior encumbrancer to be subrogated to the rights and priorities of the mortgagee who he had redeemed, could nevertheless be invoked under s. 6 of the Punjab Laws Act.
This was the only point urged in these appeals which fail and are dismissed with costsone set payable to the executors of the will of Pt. Sham Sunder.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 states appellant not permitted to argue rebutting the presumption, thereby supporting the presumption in c8 by disallowing contrary argument due to lack of pleadings.

anchor.surface_text: Accepting the Law, as expounded by Sir Richard Couch in Gokuldass Gopaldass v. Ram Bux Scochand 1 , in the following terms In India the art of conveyancing has been and is of a very simple character. Their Lordships cannot find that a formal transfer of a mortgage is ever made, or an intention to keep it alive ever formally expressed The obvious question to ask in the interests of 1 1884 L. R. 11 1. A. 126,133-134. justice, equity, and good conscience, is, what was the intention of the party paying off the charge?
This was the only point urged in these appeals which fail and are dismissed with costsone set payable to the executors of the will of Pt. Sham Sunder.

Now Mukhamal who had been impleaded as a subsequent transferee in Lajwantis suit claimed that he was entitled to marshalling on the principle to be found in s. 56 of the Transfer of Property Act which runs as follows If the owner of two or more properties mortgages them to one person and then sells one or more of the properties to another person., the buyer is, in the absence of a contract to the contrary, entitled to have the mortgage-debt satisfied out of the property or properties not sold to him, so far as the same will extend, but not so as to prejudice the rights of the mortgagee or persons claiming under him or of any other person who has for consideration acquired an interest in any of the properties.
This was the only point urged in these appeals which fail and are dismissed with costsone set payable to the executors of the will of Pt. Sham Sunder.

Learned Counsel urged two points 1 that on a proper construction of s. 56 and the principle underlying it the benefit of marshalling could not be claimed by a purchaser who happened to be a mortgagee in respect of any property belonging to the mortgagor. Learned Counsel pointed out that Mukhamal Gokul Chand had a mortgage under a deed dated February 9, 1944, over certain properties with which the appellant is not concerned.
This was the only point urged in these appeals which fail and are dismissed with costsone set payable to the executors of the will of Pt. Sham Sunder.

The other submission of learned Counsel was that the learned judges failed to give effect to the last portion of s. 56 under which marshalling is not to be permitted so as to prejudice the rights inter alia of the mortgagees or other persons claiming under him, i.e., under the original mortgagor. Learned Counsel pointed out that the appellant having proved his mortgage and the fact that it was subsisting, the learned judges of the High Court ought to have held that any direction as to marshalling must necessarily prejudice him.
This was the only point urged in these appeals which fail and are dismissed with costsone set payable to the executors of the will of Pt. Sham Sunder.
r the period of limitation had expired. The application to the High Court for companydoning this delay was supported by an affidavit by one Amar Nath.

anchor.surface_text: Mukhamals appeal to the High Court-Appeal 28 of 1948 was filed out of time with a petition for condonation of delay under s. 5 of the Indian Limitation Act and the learned judges condoned the delay and entertained the appeal.
This was the only point urged in these appeals which fail and are dismissed with costsone set payable to the executors of the will of Pt. Sham Sunder.
